entities.text: The `hanging-punctuation property` in CSS is almost a no-brainer. The classic example is a blockquote that starts with a curly-quote. Hanging that opening curly-quote into the space off to the start of the text and aligning the actual words is a better look.

entities.text:
The actual technique is pretty simple.

Build your layout as if it was fixed size, then wrap it in SVG <foreignObject> with the size you used.

Any CSS layout technique works within‚Äîflex, grid, you name it. All pixel values scale proportionally.

The browser support is great too.

entities.text:
Waiting for a train this morning: birds in the wind in the sky

Pigeons, the flock as one circling leaping swooping at the roofline

Gulls ‚Äî a handful up high, calling soaring

Crows, busy at the next platform over, up and down up and down

I am a visitor in the unwelt of others.

2 9s = 60 minutes
1 9s = 9 hours
0 9s = 90 hours

full_text:
Two more quick ones:

‚Ä¢ `-RT` ‚Äì Exclude retweets from the search
‚Ä¢ `filter:links` ‚Äì Only include tweets that link to external sites

Given how much time I spend on twitter, I often struggle to re-find things. These tricks have helped me, hope they help you too!
text:
Two more quick ones:

‚Ä¢ `-RT` ‚Äì Exclude retweets from the search
‚Ä¢ `filter:links` ‚Äì Only include tweets that link to external sites

Given how much time I spend on twitter, I often struggle to re-find things. These tricks have helped me, hope they help you too!

entities.text:
Still to this day, these are some of the best bash aliases I've ever added to my .bash_profile

alias ..="cd .."
alias ...="cd ../.."
alias ....="cd ../../.."
alias .....="cd ../../../.."
alias ......="cd ../../../../.."

Saves so much time when going up directories.

alias ......="cd ../../../../.."

Saves so much time when going up directories.

entities.text: Git tip I wish I'd discovered ten years ago: if you `git config --global diff.noprefix true` it removes the silly `a/` and `b/` prefixes so that when you double-click select one to copy, you get a usable filename instead of a mangled path.

full_text: Git tip I wish I'd discovered ten years ago: if you `git config --global diff.noprefix true` it removes the silly `a/` and `b/` prefixes so that when you double-click select one to copy, you get a usable filename instead of a mangled path. https://t.co/8COLkcClv6

entities.text:
git add -p

iterate through changes in tracked files, with the option to stage them.

git add -u

stage all changes to tracked files

git diff --cached

diff staged changes versus HEAD

git reset -p

iterate through staged changes to unstage them.

full_text:
A client asked to make a "curved bottom tabs bar" for their React Native app nav. This is where you cutout a half circle for a call to action in the middle of the bar. Like Venmo does.

I found some libs that did the job, but they all left me wanting. So I wrote the SVG by hand, https://t.co/Q91Hzdcd2u
text:
A client asked to make a "curved bottom tabs bar" for their React Native app nav. This is where you cutout a half circle for a call to action in the middle of the bar. Like Venmo does.

I found some libs that did the job, but they all left me wanting. So I wrote the SVG by hand, https://t.co/Q91Hzdcd2u

mediaDetails.ext_alt_text: A look at the curved bottom tabs bar of the Venmo app nav. It's flat from left to right and midway cuts out a semicircle downwards, so that a circular button can fit in the gap.

Before accepting a startup job offer with equity, make sure you ask the company for:

- Total number of shares
- Liquidation preferences

This will allow you to calculate the % of the company you own & value it

entities.text:
I wonder how people would emotionally respond to a language that flips the order of a for-each loop:

for [item] in [list]
for [list] as [item]

The first sounds more like English, the later lets you name your variable after you have thought about what you're looping over

mediaDetails.ext_alt_text:
Screen recording of "Shadow Palette", a tool I built that allows developers to generate custom CSS shadows. The default layout has a figure on the left showing the shadows, a control panel on the right.

On smaller screens, the figure flips to sit on top of the control panel, using sticky positioning.

The control panel is a two-column layout by default, but switches to 1-column when there isn't enough space. This means that as the viewport shrinks, it goes from 2-column, to 1-column, then back to 2-column when the figure moves.

Edge as in network is still critical for the static bits, like JS assets and PPR. The rest server-renders and streams from the cloud region.

entities.text:
The moving shelves take inventory to human pickers. Pickers remove the item in the order and place them in a bin.

Bin travel down miles of track to boxing stations.

Tracks either take the order to single unit boxing or multiple unit boxing.

Inventory is almost always moving.

mediaDetails.ext_alt_text: Three iPads (3rd generation) running iPhoto. One is displaying a photo journal with a virtual cotton texture background and images arranged in an asymmetric bento box grid. that said, it's pretty hacky and might not work for you. some limitations/known issues:

- only starts loading likes after you download the app, no way to search previous likes
- login with passkey doesn't work

that said, it's pretty hacky and might not work for you. some limitations/known issues:

entities.text:
Silicon Valley first mastered the craft of building technology, then product, then design. 

It is now learning the craft of brand and brand marketing. 

As technology markets become more competitive, brand matters more, and those who can build brand are better placed to win.

mediaDetails.ext_alt_text: iPhoto for iPad, redesigned for iOS 7. The once rich textures and bold icons have been replaced with thin icons sitting on a dark gray container. The only colors are two blue highlighted buttons and the colors in the photo.
The brush fanout has been replaced with a lifeless popover menu.

mediaDetails.ext_alt_text: The eight brushes in iPhoto fanned out from off-screen. From left to right: Repair (magic wand with sparkles floating above it), Red Eye (a black magic marker), Saturate (a wide-head paintbrush with rainbow paint), Desaturate (paintbrush with gray paint), Lighten (paintbrush with white paint), Darken (paintbrush with black paint), Sharpen (a fine paintbrush), and Soften (a foam paintbrush)
The current iOS markup tool platter. A few pens, a highlighter, an eraser, a lasso pencil, a ruler. They‚Äôre all stylized as matte white plastic.

Unity, who used to constantly annoy me with things like bad UI tools, editor instability, dependency hell... are now building the very best tools for Vision Pro.

If we find a way to attach SwiftUI to gameobjects, it's over for RK.
